author: ditcameroon
title: d-Cargo: Decentralized Cargo Dapp
description: Trucks in Cameroon are most often loaded for only one leg of their round trip journey, this is economically inefficient for the truck owner.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is a wonderful idea in promoting the efficiency of delivery tracks. In addition it will promote women empowerment in terms of the Bayam-Sellam, (people, commonly women, who buy goods in bulk to then go and sell them in other cities) who encounter a lot of difficulties in bringing the goods purchased into metropolises such as Douala and Yaoundé. If the plan is ultimately implemented successfully, it will promote the use of Cardona in Africa especially Cameroon.
f6_assessments.q1: The software developer background of the most of the team members in addition to their Wada network and their makes them highly capable to create the CARGO dapp. Also, the budget break was reasonable.  I did not understand why the proposer mentioned the "lack of initial engagement of people and communities in need" as a challenge since based on the information they provided, the efficiency of delivery trucks is a significant problem that affects the livelihood of people and needs immediate attention. If that is so, why would there be a lack of engagement?
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer provides a very easy way to track the progress of the project when implemented based on the timelines and key metrics it provided.

f6_assessments.q0: Fantastic solution and one that addresses multiple challenges. The opportunities for both truckers and individual seeking for that service would ease the communication between demand and supply and the blockchain serving as an intermediary to the process.
f6_assessments.q1: Given the experience presented, the roles and the stage by stage plan there is an abundance of knowledge in how to develop the Dapp and how to create an interface conducive of change for the problem in question. Perhaps a marketing strategy to bring into light the opportunities of this Dapp would be benefitial to its impact in the region.
f6_assessments.q2: The stage by stage plan is quite simple in approach and to the point. The funds are balanced, more detail regarding key performance indicators and perhaps projective analysis of adoption in regards of number of truckers using them, onboarding partners in that industry and marketing reach  would be benefitial to assess the metrics on performance and adoption.
f6_assessments.reply: Auditability: This project fits within the guidelines of the challenge which is more of a research and white paper implementation then building an MVP as a proof of concept therefore some of the more sepcific details and KPIs asked by the assesor will come out of this first phase.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is useful in many different ways: It will be beneficial to both people transporting cargo and to those that are in need of transport. It will reduce carbon emissions an provide a new, real life tangible usecase for blockchain. It will create many new perspectives in an apparently yet relatively untapped market. It should be scalable as well.
f6_assessments.q1: WADA have proven to be reliable and efficient proposers is the past, so I am positive they will do a good job here as well. The budget is sound and diversified, and the implementation plan consists of credible milestones and a good contingency plan. The technical details are explained well enough for a proposal. I have no doubt this proposal will be a success, especially considering WADAs track record.
f6_assessments.q2: The problem description is clear and the solution is explained very detailed. Well-made milestones are supplemented by tangible, quantifiable success metrics/KPIs. The auditablility of this proposal should be very easy. Good Job :-)

f6_assessments.q0: The idea is not bad, it is about optimizing the cargo transport service in the country of Cameroon, but it is still very abstract how Cardano's technologies would be used here. It is said that decentralized identities would be used, but how? How would Atala Prism enter this project? It is mentioned briefly that payment tokens would be generated, would be minted at Cardano, right? And these CO2 offset tokens, how would that work? Why would this all be classified as a DAO? Unfortunately, I think the authors fail to explain clearly and clearly why Dapp would be beneficial to our blockchain. They explain the problem situation and their proposed solutions very well, but dedicate little space in the impact to explain about the technological parts referring to Cardano would be used and developed. So as far as impact is concerned, I don't think we're clear on whether the challenge's objectives would actually be met.
f6_assessments.q1: This topic is more or less, some points are strong but others need to improve a lot. Starting with the script, this part is very superficial. The proponents divide the total time into 3, 6, and 12 month intervals, and explain very superficially what would happen in each of these intervals. It would have been far more appropriate if the division had been monthly, and more details had been attached about each of the activities. The money requested is well explained. The various parts that make up the whole are detailed, although these could also be further broken down (for example, how would the marketing be done?), it is possible to have a good understanding of how the budget would be used. Regarding the team, I like this part, the names and a brief resume of each professional involved are presented. Trust in them is conveyed as they are active people in the Cardano community. They say the Wada group would also participate - but other people besides these? Who, and doing what? Finally, I think the topic is not bad, but still not ideal.
f6_assessments.q2: Success would be measured by the number of Dapp users and also through a fully redacted specification document + a full white paper for future implementation + a fully functional MVP. Regarding these three things: how often would they be updated once they were created and how would the Cardano community be aware of what was new, how would they be updated with changes? I also think it's important that we monitor the work behind these partial results, in addition to the targets themselves. Talking about success, the proponents state what success would be for a period of 3, 6 and 12 months, but they focus too much on Dapp and not the repercussions of this for Cardano. How can we be sure that the specific objectives of the challenge are being met? How can we measure, quantitatively and qualitatively, the consequences for our blockchain? In my view, this is essential and is absent from the auditability of this proposal. Therefore, I believe that overall the topic should be reviewed and improved.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal he's trying to solve the problem of inefficiency in the car end transportation business in Cameroon. In fact the proponents have  noticed  that trucks sometimes make trips  with no loads. Their solution is a decentralized application  that connects people with  Transportation medium to those who seek  Freight service. I think that it is very useful to the community and should help make the transportation  in Cameroon much more efficient. For that reason this proposal  is in the scope of this challenge. I think that this proposal could also  fit the grow Africa grow cardano challenge. Altogether the proponents  have done a great job explaining the goal of this project.  I give it a five rating  because a successful implementation  of this  proposal will have a great impact on   Cameroon transportation  and the cardano   ecosystem as well.
f6_assessments.q1: I have a good confidence in the successful implementation of this project based on the information included in it.  I have  visited the LinkedIn profile of the team members, and I have to say that they are pretty knowledgeable.  Moreover they are part of the wada organization   which adds a layer of credibility on the team. However, I think that the budget looks too small for a project of this size. Perhaps they are looking to get an MVP up and running before raising more money. If that's the case, it can be a great strategy in my opinion, but the team can also clarify that. Other than that, I think that the proposal is feasible and deserves a 5 rating.
f6_assessments.q2: The proponents have provided a roadmap which predicts the launch of an MVP in 12 months post funding. They have also provided strong KPIs that define the success of the project which make it easy to track its progress. Moreover, they are planning to deliver great documentation including a whitepaper which should be great for the community. Altogether, I think that this project is awesome and auditable.

f6_assessments.q0: Every once in a while you come across a blockchain proposal that leaves you asking: what do you need the blockchain for? This might just be one of them. This d-Cargo is essentially a matchmaking service for trucks returning empty and customers who need transport for their stuff. Yep, there are some mentions about Atala PRISM, tokenization, native tokens and a DAO but none of this is needed to solve the problem. All it takes is a (Web2) mobile app with email, SMS and push notifications.
f6_assessments.q1: It’s a great team and the proposal is not asking for a lot of money: $9,000 only. The scope of this proposal is creation of a minimum viable product, a white paper and specifications. They most likely deliver. Apart from the fact that this probably wouldn’t need to be a blockchain dApp, I have no other criticism.
f6_assessments.q2: The use case is laid out clearly and the plan is understandable. The budget is very reasonable. It would have to be explained, however, why this has to be built on Cardano. Identity and access management doesn’t have to be necessarily decentralized. Route and load optimization is probably easier without blockchain. There are definitely easier established ways for carbon offsetting. Dealing directly in local currencies is more straightforward. And the app can be built as a simple mobile app.

f6_assessments.q0:
The problem described is reasonable, but the proposal could have provided data/articles/information that could support the freight problems in Cameroon.

The idea of the app itself is relevant in view of the problem described, but it would be important to better describe how the blockchain will be used in this application. There is a big difference between an app and a dapp. A dapp is built with decentralization and blockchain integration in mind. Most existing dapps do not need to use blockchain for their use, using blockchain increases cost and friction for users. This proposal does not adequately articulate the reasons for developing this dapp using blockchain technology. The only mention that allows creating an association between the app and the blockchain would be the use of a reputation system through Atala Prism, so it would be important for the proposal to describe this component in more detail, as well as the purpose of the aforementioned DAO, so that it is possible to understand how the blockchain will be used in the app.

The intention to create a model with native assets for payments was mentioned, but the dapp will not use crypto transactions at this time(MVP version).

The proposal includes some metrics, but the only target indicator included in the proposal (KPI) was 100s of users signing up and engaging in this DAO in 12 months. It would be important to establish KPIs/indicators with complementary targets to make it easier to identify the potential of the proposal, because only with the KPI provided we only know which users will sign up, there are no KPIs that allow us to understand the use of the dapp itself.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team has relevant experience in software development, including Haskell, but there is no mention if any member of the team has experience with Plutus. There are sources to verify the statements and experiences of the team.

WADA has been developing several projects in the Cardano community and the team members have a high reputation on Catalyst.

The proposal describes a budget breakdown, but this could be more detailed.

e.g. A $1000 allocation for marketing has been set, but there is no mention of what the marketing plan will involve other than mentions of social media usage without details. Resource allocation for developers has been defined, but there is no hourly workload estimate for development and it is not clear how the application will use blockchain. An allocation of $1,000 was set for "Ground surveys & interview logistics (recording materials, and displacement costs)" without explaining how these interviews will be.

Regarding the roadmap presented in the feasibility part, there is little information, there is not enough detail to understand the development of the project over the 12-month period. I believe that the development time is appropriate to develop the type of application intended, but due to the lack of details in the roadmap, the feasibility assessment ends up being hampered.

The proposer considered challenges for development and proposed appropriate solutions.

I believe that the main improvements that could be made would be a better detailing of how blockchain technology will be used in this proposal, more precisely the use of a model of reputation, governance and the possible use of a native asset.
f6_assessments.q2:
There is clarity in the target problem, but the proposer could include more information/data/articles to improve understanding of the freight context in Cameroon. The solution presented is reasonable, but it would be important to better detail how the blockchain will be used.

The roadmap needs better detail, inclusion of more deliverables/milestones over the 12 months to facilitate auditing.

Relevant metrics were included, but only one KPI was included, I recommend the inclusion of more KPIs(indicators with targets) that allow evaluating the performance of the dapp in relation to the number of users, transactions and product quality.
